introduction.p: In addition to the scalar or dot product we discussed above, there is another type of multiplication between two vectors. We call the second type of multiplication a vector or cross product, since this time, the result is also a vector, not just a simple number as was the case with the dot product. Since, the vector product results in a vector, we need to specify the result either in terms of the component form of the answer or the magnitude and direction form.

sidebyside.p: The Right Hand Rule for vector/cross product: If you point the thumb of your right hand in the direction of vector \vec A , and point any other finger in the direction of vector \vec B , then their vector product, vector \vec C will be perpendicular to your palm and coming out of the palm.

introduction.p:
It is often more convenient to write the result of the vector product between vectors \vec A and \vec B in terms of the components of \vec A and \vec B . Since the result is a vector, we state the components of the result in terms of the components of \vec A and \vec B .
\amp (\vec A \times \vec B)_x = A_y B_z - A_z B_y, \amp (\vec A \times \vec B)_y = A_z B_x - A_x B_z, \amp (\vec A \times \vec B)_z = A_x B_y - A_y B_x,

From these components of \vec A \times \vec B or from the way right had rule operates, you can show that the if you change the order of \vec A and \vec B , then you would get the result pointed in the opposite direction.
\vec B \times \vec A = - \vec A \times \vec B.

Another important thing to notice is that the product depends on the angle between the vectors through \sin\, \theta . Thus, if \theta = 0 or 180^{\circ}, the cross prosuct will be zero. That is, the cross product of parallel or anti-parallel vectors is always zero.

example.title: Cross Product Using Components of Vectors

statement.p: A particle located at (x, y, z) = (3, -2, 5) , where distances are in the unit \text{m} , is subject to a force whose components are (F_x, F_y, F_z) = (-10, 30, -20 ) in units of \text{N}. Find the components of torque on the particle given by \vec r \times \vec F.

p.m: -110\text{ N.m }\hat i + 10\text{ N.m }\hat j + 70\text{ N.m }\hat k.

solution.p:
You may recall that x, \, y,\, z are the components of the position vector \vec r . Therefore to get the components of \vec r \times \vec F we just use the formulas given.
(\vec r \times \vec F)_x \amp = y F_z - z F_y \amp = (-2)\times(-20) - 5\times 30 = -110
(\vec r \times \vec F)_y \amp = z F_x - x F_z \amp = 5\times(-10) - 3\times (-20) = 10
(\vec r \times \vec F)_z \amp = x F_y - y F_x \amp = 3\times 30 - (-2)\times (-10) = 70
Therefore,
\vec \tau = -110\text{ N.m }\hat i + 10\text{ N.m }\hat j + 70\text{ N.m }\hat k.

example.title: Magnetic Force on a Current Carrying Wire

statement.p: The force on a straight wire of length L carrying a current I placed between the poles of a horse-shoe magnet is given by the formula I \vec L \times \vec B , where \vec L is a vector of length same as the length of the wire and the direction the same as the direction of current flow, and \vec B is the magnetic field vector.

In a physics lab, L = 0.20 \text{ meter}, I = 10.0 \text{ Amperes}, and B = 1.5 \text{ Tesla} . The direction of \vec B is up and the direction of current flow is North. (a) What is the angle between \vec L and \vec B ? (b) What are the magnitude and direction of the force on the wire?

solution.p: (a) The angle between Up and North directions is 90^{\circ}.

exercise.title: Practice with the Right Hand Rule

statement.p: Vector \vec A is pointed towards East and vector \vec B is pointed towards North. (a) Which way is the cross product \vec A \times \vec B pointed? (b) Which way is the cross product \vec B \times \vec A pointed?

solution.p: (a) Using right-hand rule, gives the answer "UP" for the direction of \vec A \times \vec B .
(b) Using right-hand rule, gives the answer "DOWN" for the direction of \vec B\times \vec A .

statement.p:
Evaluate the vector products:
\left[(3\ \textrm{m})\ \hat u_x\right. + \left.(4\ \textrm{m})\ \hat u_y\right] \times \left[(10\ \textrm{N})\ \hat u_x\right. + \left.(-5\ \textrm{N})\ \hat u_y\right],
\left[ (3\ \textrm{m})\ \hat u_x\right. + \left.(4\ \textrm{m})\ \hat u_z \right] \times \left[(40\ \textrm{N})\ \hat u_x\right. + \left.(-10\ \textrm{N})\ \hat u_y \right],
\left[ (30\ \textrm{m})\ \hat u_y\right. + \left.(4\ \textrm{m})\ \hat u_z \right] \times \left[ (100\ \textrm{N})\ \hat u_x\right. + \left.(-10\ \textrm{N})\ \hat u_y \right],
\left[ (4\ \textrm{m/s})\ \hat u_x\right. + (3\ \textrm{m/s})\ \hat u_y + \left.(2\ \textrm{m/s})\ \hat u_z \right] \times \left[ (2\ \textrm{N})\ \hat u_x\right. + (3\ \textrm{N})\ \hat u_y + \left.(4\ \textrm{N})\ \hat u_z \right],
\left[ (30\ \textrm{m/s})\ \hat u_y\right. + \left.(4\ \textrm{m/s})\ \hat u_z \right] \times \left[ (100\ \textrm{N})\ \hat u_x\right. + (-10\ \textrm{N})\ \hat u_y + \left.(100\ \textrm{N})\ \hat u_z \right].

solution.title: a
solution.p:
We can perform the vector product by expanding out the products and using the formulas of the vector products between the unit vectors. However, a more common practice is to use the matrix method to organize the calculations.
\amp \left[(3\ \textrm{m})\ \hat u_x\right. + \left.(4\ \textrm{m})\ \hat u_y\right] \times \left[(10\ \textrm{N})\ \hat u_x\right. + \left.(-5\ \textrm{N})\ \hat u_y\right]
\amp = \left| \begin{array}{ccc} \hat u_x \amp \hat u_y \amp \hat u_z\\ 3\ \textrm{m} \ \amp 4\ \textrm{m} \ \amp 0\\ 10\ \textrm{N} \ \amp -5\ \textrm{N} \ \amp 0 \end{array} \right|
\amp = \hat u_z [3\times (-5) - 4\times 10]\ \textrm{N.m}= (-55\ \textrm{N.m}) \hat u_z.
Sometimes it is helpful to drop the units when writing the determinant and put the units back in at the end of the calculations.

md.mrow: \amp \left[ (4\ \textrm{m/s})\ \hat u_x\right. + (3\ \textrm{m/s})\ \hat u_y + \left.(2\ \textrm{m/s})\ \hat u_z \right] \times \left[ (2\ \textrm{N})\ \hat u_x\right. + (3\ \textrm{N})\ \hat u_y + \left.(4\ \textrm{N})\ \hat u_z \right]

exercise.title: Computing Dot and Cross Products of Displacement and Force Vectors

statement.p: Consider a force vector \vec F that has a magnitude 25.0\text{ N} in the direction of East and a displacement vector \vec r that has a magnitude 4.0\text{ m} in the direction of 30^{\circ} North of East. For stating directions in space, let x axis be pointed towards East, y axis be pointed towards North, and z axis be pointed Up. Find (a) \vec r \cdot \vec F , and (b) \vec r \times \vec F .

hint.p: Use formulas in terms of magnitudes and angle.

answer.p: (a) 86.6\text{ N.m} , (b) ( 50.0\text{ N.m} , in the negative z axis direction).

solution.p: Since magnitudes of the two vectors and the angle between them are given, we can just use the defining formula for the dot product to get the value of the dot product and magnitude of the cross product. To find the direction of the cross product, we use the right hand rule given in the definition.

(a) The dot product:
\vec r \cdot \vec F \amp = r\, F\, \cos\, \theta \amp = 4.0\text{ m}\times 25.0\text{ N}\times\cos\, 30^{\circ} = 86.6\text{ N.m}.

(b) The cross product \vec r \times \vec F :
\text{Magnitude } \amp = r\, F\, \sin\, \theta \amp = 4.0\text{ m}\times 25.0\text{ N}\times\sin\, 30^{\circ} = 50.0\text{ N.m}.

sidebyside.p: We obtain the direction of \vec r \times \vec F vector by using the right hand rule. One way to do that is shown in this figure. I sweep my right hand from \vec r towards \vec F , then the thumb points down into the page, which is the negative z axis direction. Another way is to point thumb in the direction of \vec r and any of the other fingers towards \vec F , then you would find that your palm points down.

exercise.title: Computing Dot and Cross Products of Displacement and Force Vectors

statement.p: Consider a force vector \vec F that has a magnitude 25.0\text{ N} in the direction of East and a displacement vector \vec r that has a magnitude 4.0\text{ m} in the direction of 30^{\circ} South of East. For stating directions in space, let x axis be pointed towards East, y axis be pointed towards North, and z axis be pointed Up. Find (a) \vec r \cdot \vec F , and (b) \vec r \times \vec F .

answer.p: (a) 86.6\text{ N.m} , (b) ( 50.0\text{ N.m} , in the positive z axis direction).

solution.p: See . The only thing new is the result of the right hand rule.

exercise.title: Dot and Cross Products of Oppositely Directed Vectors

statement.p: Consider a force vector \vec F that has a magnitude 25.0\text{ N} in the direction of East and a displacement vector \vec r that has a magnitude 4.0\text{ m} in the direction of West. For stating directions in space, let x axis be pointed towards East, y axis be pointed towards North, and z axis be pointed Up. Find (a) \vec r \cdot \vec F , and (b) \vec r \times \vec F .

solution.p:
Here the angle between the two vectors are 180^{\circ} . Therefore, we have
\cos\,\theta = -1,\ \ \sin\, \theta = 0.
Therefore, the dot product will give \vec r \cdot \vec F = -100.0\text{ N.m}, and the magnitude of the cross product will be 100.0 \times 0 = 0. Since the magnitude of the cross product is zero, it is zero vector, and hence its direction is indeterminate.

exercise.title: Dot and Cross Products of Perpendicularly Directed Vectors

statement.p: Consider a force vector \vec F that has a magnitude 25.0\text{ N} in the direction of East and a displacement vector \vec r that has a magnitude 4.0\text{ m} in the direction of North. For stating directions in space, let x axis be pointed towards East, y axis be pointed towards North, and z axis be pointed Up. Find (a) \vec r \cdot \vec F , and (b) \vec r \times \vec F .

answer.p: (a) 0 , (b) ( 100.0\text{ N.m} , in the negative z axis direction).

solution.p:
Here the angle between the two vectors are 90^{\circ} . Therefore, we have
\cos\,\theta = 0,\ \ \sin\, \theta = 1.
Therefore, the dot product will give \vec r \cdot \vec F = 0, and the magnitude of the cross product will be 100.0 \text{ N.m}. Using the right-hand rule, you can deduce the direction to be into-the-page direcion, which is the direction of the negative z axis.
